Award.AwardTitle: Matching Supply and Demand Through Dual-Sourcing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
It has become increasingly challenging to match supply and demand as firms have extended their supply chains to a global scale. One major concern for many multi-national firms with global supply networks is supply uncertainty, especially supply disruption. Another big concern is the reduced responsiveness due to longer lead times. Dual-sourcing has been commonly implemented in practice as an effective strategy to mitigate supply risks and provide a tradeoff between cost and responsiveness. This practice calls for advanced dual-sourcing models that incorporate supply uncertainty and large replenishment lead times simultaneously, and the development and analysis of effective inventory strategies. The objective of this research is to provide a comprehensive understanding of complex dual-sourcing systems as well as provide new insights and analytical tools to handle this level of complexity. The research has the potential to provide new tools and methodologies to effectively manage value chain systems and thus improve companies' competitive advantage. In addition, it will provide educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and has the potential to broaden participation of underrepresented groups and minorities through the Multi-Cultural Engineering Recruitment for Graduate Education Program (MERGE) at the University of Illinois.

If successful, the results of this project will have a significant impact on the theory and practice of dual-sourcing inventory optimization. First, the research will develop novel transformation techniques to convert non-convex minimization problems to equivalent convex minimization problems applicable to complex dual-sourcing models. Second, the research will, provide theoretic support of several heuristics widely used in practice, design new efficient algorithms, and explore potential applications of the advanced methodologies developed under the auspices of this project in other problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It becomes increasingly challenging to match supply and demand as firms extend their supply chains at a global scale. One major concern for many multi-national firms with global supply networks is supply uncertainty, especially supply disruption. Another big concern is the reduced responsiveness due to longer lead times. Dual sourcing has been commonly implemented in practice as an effective strategy to mitigate supply risks and provide a delicate tradeoff between cost and responsiveness. Motivated by this practice, in this project, we developed sophisticated dual sourcing models incorporating supply uncertainty and large replenishment lead time which allow to properly evaluate the tradeoffs among risk, cost and responsiveness.

These models lead to challenging high dimensional non-convex stochastic dynamic optimization problems. To address the challenge, we developed a novel transformation technique to convert non-convex minimization problems to equivalent convex minimization problems. The transformation technique allowed us to derive the structure of the optimal policies of complex dual sourcing models and design efficient algorithms. It also found important applications including general inventory models with supply capacity uncertainty and revenue management models using booking limit controls. We proved the asymptotical optimality of some open-loop control policies in a class of Markov decision processes when the actions affect the systems after long lead times, which provides theoretic support of several inventory replenishment heuristics widely used in practice. Our work established connections with discrete convex analysis. We identified a variety of new applications of discrete convexity in operations and develop a novel concept of S-convexity which is closely related to gross substitutability, an important concept in economics. Our new models and techniques significantly advance our knowledge base in supply chain management and revenue management and provide frameworks, tools and insights to understand complex operations models.   Our research led to publications in high quality academic journals, and provided graduate students with solid analytical training and prepared them for the job markets which call for sophisticated analytical skills.
